metadata.title: Electrochemical determination of bisphenol A at ordered mesoporous carbon modified nano-carbon ionic liquid paste electrode

sections.text:
ordered mesoporous carbon CMK-3 modified nano-carbon ionic liquid paste electrode (CMK-3/nano-CILPE). The nanostructure of CMK-3 and the surface morphologies of modified electrodes were characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Electrochemical properties of the fabricated electrodes were investigated by cyclic voltammetry (CV) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). The fabricated sensor displayed excellent electroactivity towards bisphenol A using linear sweep voltammetry (LSV).

Experimental conditions influencing the analytical performance of the modified electrode were optimized. Under optimal conditions, the oxidation peak current was proportional to BPA concentration in the range from 0.2 μM to 150 μM with a detection limit of 0.05 μM (S/N = 3). This method was successfully used for determination of BPA leached from drinking bottle and plastic bag with good recoveries. Key words: Bisphenol A; ordered mesoporous carbon; nano-carbon ionic liquid paste electrode; Linear sweep voltammetry

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Bisphenol A (BPA) is an estrogenic environmental toxin, and it is widely used in
the production of polycarbonate plastics, epoxy resins, flame retardants, and so on [1-3]. Under certain conditions BPA can be released into environment from the bottles, packaging, plastics plants and landfill leachates, and it has proved to be a potential risk to public health. A certain amount of BPA may cause impaired brain development, sexual differentiation, behavior, and affect immune function. Therefore, it is necessary to establish a simple and sensitive method for the determination of trace amounts of BPA.
BPA is an electroactive substance with hydroxide radical, so electrochemical
methods are convenient for detecting BPA. Compared with other reported analytical methods [4-6], electrochemical methods possess the advantages, such as simple operation, fast response, high sensitivity, excellent selectivity, and low cost. In addition, electrochemical methods provide a practical tool for on-line or field monitoring. Some modified electrodes have been developed for investigating the electrochemical behavior of BPA [7-17]. Though some satisfactory results have been obtained, it is still a challenge to develop new, simpler and more convenient methods for BPA determination.
Various nanomaterials have been utilized to modify the bare electrode in order to
promote the electron transfer rate and improve the selectivity of sensors. Ordered mesoporous carbon (OMC) with unique nanostructure and properties has attracted considerable attention in recent years. OMC possesses large surface area, well defined pore size and pore volume, good conductivity, high thermal stability, flexible framework composition and chemical inertness [18-20]. It shows better performance on the adsorption of various organic pollutants, including BPA [21, 22].
Traditional carbon paste electrodes (CPEs) are composed of graphite powders
and paraffin oil. In recent years, the components are gradually replaced by new materials, for example, ionic liquids are used as binders instead of paraffin oil. Ionic liquids possess high ionic conductivity and high viscosity, and they are promising candidate materials for fabrication of electrochemical sensors. The developed ionic liquid-based carbon paste electrodes provide a fast electron transfer rate and a decrease in the overpotentials of some organic compounds [23, 24].
The electrochemical oxidation of BPA at the ordered mesoporous carbon CMK-3
modified nano-carbon ionic liquid paste electrode (CMK-3/nano-CILPE) has not been studied. The nano-carbon ionic liquid paste electrode (nano-CILPE) was composed of nano-graphite powders, ionic liquid and paraffin oil. The charge transfer resistance of the modified electrode was significantly reduced using nano-graphite powders instead of graphite powders. Additionally, the nano-CILPE displayed lower background current and enhanced conductivity using the mixture of ionic liquid and paraffin oil as binders. The prepared sensor showed good electrocatalytic activity to BPA due to large surface area and absorption capability of CMK-3 and high conductivity of ionic liquid. The proposed sensor displayed low resistance, ease of modification and renewability, low cost, faster electron transfer, and high sensitivity. Moreover, the novel method was successfully applied to the detection of BPA leached from drinking bottle and plastic bag. The simple and convenient BPA sensor exhibited its potential application in the monitoring of food safety and environmental pollution.
2. Experimental

sections.heading: 2.1. Reagents and materials
sections.text:
The ionic liquid 1-butylpyridinium hexafluorophosphate (BPPF6) was purchased
from Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics (Lanzhou, China, http://www.ionicliquid.org), graphite powder (spectrographic grade) and paraffin oil were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China, http://www.sinoreagent.com). Nano-graphite powder (thickness: ＜40 nm, sheet size: about 400 nm) and CMK-3 (surface area: ＞900 m2/g) were purchased from Nanjing XFNANO Materials Tech Co., Ltd. (Nanjing, China, http://www.xfnano.com). Bisphenol A (BPA) was purchased from Xiya Reagent Co., Ltd (http://www.xiyashiji.com). 0.1 M phosphate buffer solution (PBS) of various pH values were used as the supporting electrolytes. All other reagents were of analytical grade, and were used without further purification.

sections.heading: 2.2. Apparatus
sections.text:
All electrochemical measurements (except electrochemical impedance
spectroscopy measurements) were performed using a CHI660E electrochemical workstation (Shanghai Chenhua Instruments Corporation, shanghai, China, http://www.chinstr.com). The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were carried by a PARSTAT 4000 (Princeton Applied Research, America, http://www.par-solartron.com.cn). A three-electrode system was used containing a CMK-3/nano-CILPE (3.0 mm in diameter), a platinum wire (0.5 mm in diameter), and a saturated calomel electrode (SCE). All potentials were reported with respect to the reference electrode (SCE). The transmission electron micrographs (TEM) were obtained with a Hitachi H-7650 transmission electron microscopy (Hitachi Ltd., Tokyo, Japan). The scanning electron micrographs (SEM) were obtained using a Hitachi S-3400 scanning electron microscope (Hitachi Ltd., Tokyo, Japan). A magnetic stirrer (Model 85-2) was used to stir the testing solution before measurements. All the experiments were carried out at room temperature.

sections.heading: 2.3. Electrode preparation
sections.text:
CMK-3 modified nano-carbon ionic liquid paste electrode (CMK-3/nano-CILPE)
was prepared by the following procedure: A certain proportion of nano-graphite powder, CMK-3, 1-butylpyridinium hexafluorophosphate and paraffin oil were mixed together in a mortar, then the mixture was packed firmly into the cavity of a teflon holder (3.0 mm in diameter) and the electrical contact was established via a copper wire. The electrode was simply heated using a hair drier for 2 min. Then it was left to cool to room temperature. A new surface was obtained by smoothing the electrode onto a piece of weighing paper. The prepared electrode was denoted as CMK-3/nano-CILPE.
For comparison, the CMK-3 modified nano-carbon paste electrode
(CMK-3/nano-CPE) was prepared by mixing nano-graphite powder, CMK-3 and paraffin oil without ionic liquid. Then a certain proportion of nano-graphite powder, 1-butylpyridinium hexafluorophosphate and paraffin oil were mixed for construction of nano-carbon ionic liquid paste electrode (nano-CILPE). In addition, nano-carbon paste electrode (nano-CPE) was made up of nano-graphite powder and paraffin oils. Compared with nano-CPE, traditional carbon paste electrode (CPE) was prepared using graphite powder instead of nano-graphite powder. When not in use, the modified electrodes were kept in air with a cover to protect them from dust.

sections.heading: 2.4. Analytical procedure
sections.text:
Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was used for investigating the electrochemical
behavior of BPA in 0.1 M PBS (pH 7.0). After an accumulation of 180 s under open-circuit condition, the voltammograms were recorded from 0.2 V to 0.8 V, scan rate was 50 mV s− 1 . After every measurement, the electrode was rinsed by ultrapure water. A new surface was obtained by smoothing the electrode onto the weighing paper.

sections.heading: 3.1. Morphological characterization
sections.text:
The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was employed to investigate the
nanostructure of CMK-3 Fig. 1F was the TEM image of CMK-3, it exhibited well defined pore size and pore volume, providing large specific surface area. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was used for characterizing the surface morphologies of different electrodes. The surface of CPE (shown in Fig. 1A) displayed the isolated flake graphite with clearly distinguished layer. Due to the presence of non-conductive binder paraffin oil, the conductivity between graphite layers was blocked along the vertical direction of planes. When the common graphite powder was replaced by nano-graphite powder, uniform surface morphologies and the narrower gaps between carbon layers could be observed on nano-CPE (Fig. 1B) and CMK-3/nano-CPE (Fig. 1C). Due to CMK-3 was homogeneously mixed in the carbon paste, we couldn’t observe its nano-structure on CMK-3/nano-CPE. As shown in Fig. 1D and Fig.1E, the surface of CILPE and CMK-3/nano-CILPE were uniform and no separated carbon layers could be observed. Due to its high viscosity, ionic liquid was easily filled into the interstice between graphite layers and bridged the carbon flakes, which lead to improved conductive performance of the modified electrodes. Aslo the nano-structure of CMK-3 couldn’t be observed on the CMK-3/ nano-CILPE.

sections.heading: 3.2. Electrochemical characterisation of the modified electrode
sections.text:
Electrochemical behaviours of the modified electrodes were investigated using
[Fe(CN)6] 3-/4- as redox probes by cyclic voltammetry. Fig. 2 shows the cyclic voltammograms of CPE (a), nano-CPE (b), CMK-3/nano-CPE (c), nano-CILPE (d), and CMK-3/ nano-CILPE (e) in 5 mM [Fe(CN)6] 3-/4- solution containing 0.1 M KCl.
At bare CPE (Curve a), no obvious peaks could be observed. A couple of redox peaks was observed at nano-CPE (Curve b) with anodic peak current (Ipa) of 4.97×10 -4 A cm -2 and peak-to-peak separation (ΔEp) of 0.295 V. The Ipa (about 9.79×10-4 A cm -2 ) achieved at CMK-3/nano-CPE (Curve c) was found almost 2-fold larger than that achieved at nano-CPE, and the ΔEp reduced to 0.238 V. The phenomenon could be attributed to the good conductivity and the large surface area of CMK-3. When ionic liquid was added on nano-CPE (Curve d), a remarkable decrease in ΔEp (about 0.108 V) and an obvious increase in Ipa (about 1.54×10-3 A cm-2) were obtained, indicating that ionic liquid could effectively increase the electron transfer rate between electrode surface and [Fe(CN)6] 3-/4- . When CMK-3 and ionic liquid were modified on the nano-CPE surface together (Curve e), theΔEp (about 0.095 V) further decreased and the Ipa (about 2.24×10-3 A cm-2) further increased, indicating that CMK-3/ionic liquid composite film allowed better adsorption and electron transfer ability for [Fe(CN)6] 3-/4- probes than pure CMK-3 or ionic liquid.
Here Fig. 2
Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was employed for further
characterisation of the modified electrode. The charge transfer resistance (Rct) is directly related to the electron transfer kinetics of the redox probe at the electrode surface, and the Rct value can be calculated by measuring the diameter of the high-frequency semicircle in the Nyquist plots. Fig. 3 exhibits the Nyquist diagrams of bare CPE (A), nano-CPE (B-b), CMK-3/nano-CPE (B-a), nano-CILPE (C-b), and CMK-3/nano-CILPE (C-a) in 5 mM [Fe(CN)6] 3-/4- containing 0.1 M KCl. By fitting the data using an appropriate equivalent circuit, the Rct value of 40.45 kΩ was obtained at bare CPE, indicating large interface impedance. The resistance value (Rct = 1.26 kΩ) remarkably decreased after graphite powder was replaced by nano-graphite powder (curve B-b). When CMK-3 was modified on the nano-CPE surface (curve B-a), the semicircle further decreased (Rct = 653.30 Ω), indicating CMK-3 could significantly increase the electrode surface area and provide more active sites. The Rct value of nano-CILPE (curve C-b) was about 38.94 Ω, which might be attributed to the good conductivity of ionic liquid. The CMK-3/ nano-CILPE
(curve C-a) showed lower interface electron resistance (Rct = 6.78 Ω) than that of nano-CILPE, and the electron transfer rate was improved, which could be ascribed to cooperative action between CMK-3 and ionic liquid.
Here Fig. 3

sections.heading: 3.3. Surface area study
sections.text:
The surface areas of nano-CPE, CMK-3/nano-CPE, nano-CILPE and CMK-3/
nano-CILPE were discussed by cyclic voltammetry in 5.0 mmol L -1 [Fe(CN)6] 3-/4- and 0.1 mol L -1 KCl solution. The cyclic voltammograms of different electrodes at different scan rates are shown in Supplementary Fig. S1. For a reversible process, the peak current (Ip) is linearly proportional to square root of scan rates (v 1/2 ) as follows (the Randles-Sevcik formula) [25]:
Ip = (2.69 × 10 5 ) n 3/2 AC0DR 1/2 v 1/2 (1) where Ip refers to the anodic peak current (A), n is the electron transfer number,
A is the surface area of the electrode (cm 2 ), C0 is concentration of K3Fe(CN)6 (mol L -1 ) and v is the scan rate (V s -1
). For K3Fe(CN)6, the electron transfer number n = 1 and
the diffusion coefficient DR = 7.60 × 10 -6 cm 2 s -1 (0.1 mol L -1 KCl). Thus, from the slope of the anodic peak current (Ipa) versus square root of scan rate (v 1/2 ) relation, the surface areas of nano-CPE, CMK-3/nano-CPE, nano-CILPE and CMK-3/ nano-CILPE were calculated to be 0.046 cm 2 , 0.065 cm 2 , 0.132 cm 2 , and 0.159 cm 2 , respectively, indicating that the effective electroactive surface of the modified electrode was remarkably increased in the presence of CMK-3 and ionic liquids.

sections.heading: 3.4. Electrochemical behaviors of bisphenol A
sections.text:
Fig. 4 exhibits the linear sweep voltammograms (LSVs) of 50 uM BPA in 0.1 M PBS (pH 7.0) obtained at different electrodes. At the bare CPE (curve a), the oxidation peak of BPA occured at about 0.556 V with a low peak current. The oxidation current at nano-CPE (curve b) was higher than that at CPE, indicating that
nano-graphite powder had good facilitation ability in the electron transfer process. When CMK-3 was modified on the surface of nano-CPE (curve c), a higher current response was observed. The phenomenon could be explained as CMK-3 increased the effective area of the modified electrode and provided more adsorption sites. The nano-CILPE (curve d) showed a decrease of the overpotential and an enhancement of the peak current on the BPA oxidation, exhibiting significant catalytic effect to BPA. It was ascribed to the good conductivity of ionic liquid. Furthermore, the highest current response was observed at CMK-3/nano-CILPE (curve e), which could be attributed to the synergistic effect of CMK-3 and ionic liquid. In the supporting electrolyte of pH 7.0, the oxidation potential of BPA at CMK-3/ nano-CILPE (about 0.493 V) was much lower than that at some reported electrodes, such as CS-Fe3O4/GCE (0.541 V vs. SCE, pH 8.0) [26], GR/ABPE (0.599 V vs. SCE, pH 7.5) [27], and PAMAM/Fe3O4/GCE (0.541 V vs. SCE, pH 7.0) [28], indicating that the CMK-3 and ionic liquid composite was an effective mediator in the electrocatalytic oxidation of BPA.

sections.heading: 3.5. scan rate
sections.text:
The influence of scan rate (v) on the electrochemical response of 50 μM BPA in
0.1 M PBS (pH 7.0) at CMK-3/ nano-CILPE was investigated by cyclic voltammetry, and the results were shown in Fig. 5. As shown in Fig. 5A, the oxidation peak current (Ipa) of BPA increased as the increase of scan rate in the range from 25 to 300 mV s− 1 . The oxidation peak current of BPA was proportional to the scan rate (shown in Fig. 5B), and the linear equation could be expressed as follows: Ipa (μA) = 0.3511 v (mV s −1) + 17.5333 (r 2 = 0.9903), suggesting that the oxidation of BPA at CMK-3/ nano-CILPE was a typical adsorption-controlled electrode process. In addition, the oxidation peak potential (Epa) shifted positively with the increase of scan rate, and showed a linear relationship with the logarithm of scan rate (lnv) (shown in Fig. 5C): Epa = 0.0288 lnv + 0.5970 (r 2 = 0.9976, Epa in V and v in V s -1 ). sections.heading: 3.6.1. Effect of pH value
sections.text:
The effect of pH value on the anodic peak current (Ipa) and potential (Epa) of 50 μM BPA was investigated, and the results were shown in Fig. 6A. The Ipa gradually increased with an increasing pH value from 5.0 to 7. 0, and reached a maximum at pH 7.0. The further increase of the pH value made the current response decrease. The phenomenon could be explained by the following reasons: The pH value of solution could affect the existing form of BPA. The pKa of BPA was 9.73. when pH < 9, BPA was non-dissociated, while at higher pH values, BPA mainly existed in the form of ion. The non-dissociated BPA was easily adsorbed to the electrode surface than the dissociated BPA, so the maximum current response correspond to the pH value was lower than the pKa of BPA [17]. The results indicated that pH 7.0 was fit for the
subsequent experiments.
In addition, the Epa shifted negatively with the increase of the pH value. A good linear relationship was obtained between the Epa and pH values (shown in Fig. 6B), and the linear equation was: Epa (V) = −0.0623 pH + 0.9351 (r2 = 0.9901). A slope of −62.3 mV pH-1 was found, close to the theoretical value of 57.6 mV pH−1, indicating that equal numbers of electrons and protons were involved in the electrooxidation of BPA on the modified electrode [30]. In Section 3.5, the electron transfer number (n) was calculated to be 2. sections.heading: 3.6.2. Effect of the amount of the modifier
sections.text:
The effect of the amount of the modifier CMK-3 in carbon paste on the current
response for 50 μM BPA was investigated by LSV. As shown in Fig. 6C, the current response increased with increasing amount of CMK-3 in carbon paste and reached the maximum at 5%, then the further increase of CMK-3 caused a gradual decrease of current response. The phenomenon could be ascribed to the following reasons: A certain amount of CMK-3 could increase the effective surface area and improve the absorption ability of the modified electrode, and promoted the oxidation of BPA, resulting in increase of oxidation peak current. However, excessive CMK-3 in carbon paste would increase the film thickness, making the electron transfer more difficult, so the oxidation peak current decreased. Therefore, 5% CMK-3 in carbon paste was chosen for all subsequent experiments.
3.6.3. Accumulation potential and accumulation time
Because the oxidation of BPA at CMK-3/nano-CILPE was a typical
adsorption-controlled electrode process, the accumulation step could increase the amount of BPA on the electrode surface and make the current response increase. We discussed the effect of the accumulation potential and open-circuit condition on oxidation of BPA with the same accumulation time (not shown). The current response was not significantly changed under an accumulation potential compared with that under open-circuit condition, but the oxidation peak potential of BPA appeared at more positive position under an accumulation potential. So we chose the open-circuit condition. Fig. 6D exhibits effect of accumulation time on the oxidation peak current of BPA under open-circuit condition. The current increased gradually with accumulation time increasing from 0 to 180 s. With further increase of the accumulation time, the oxidation peak current increased slightly, suggesting that absorption amount of BPA on the modified electrode reached saturation. Considering both sensitivity and working efficiency, 180 s was chosen as the optimal accumulation time.

sections.heading: 3.7. Determination of bisphenol A
sections.text:
Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was used to investigate the sensing
performance of CMK-3/nano-CILPE towards BPA. Fig. 7 shows LSVs for various concentrations of BPA in 0.1M PBS (pH 7.0) at the modified electrode. Under the optimized conditions, the oxidation peak currents increased linearly with BPA concentrations in the range from 0.2 μM to 150 μM, with the linear regression equations as I (μA) = 0.7741 c (μM)+7.5795 (r 2 =0.9938). With the further increase of BPA concentration, the peak current increased slowly. The detection limit was calculated as 0.05 μM at a ratio of signal to noise of 3.

sections.heading: 3.8. Reproducibility and stability
sections.text:
Reproducibility and stability are key parameters for the performance of a sensor.
Six modified electrodes prepared using the same procedure were utilized for the determination of 50 μM BPA, and the relative standard deviation (RSD) of the response current was 4.6%. The results revealed that the sensor had good reproducibility. When not in use, the electrode was stored in room temperature. The current response of 50 μM BPA retained 95.7% of the initial current after one month, which exhibited that the modified electrode had good stability.

sections.heading: 3.9. Interference of coexisting substances
sections.text:
The influence of some potential coexisting substances was investigated in 0.1 M
PBS (pH 7.0) containing 10 μM BPA in order to evaluate the selectivity of the modified electrode, which was shown in Supplementary Table S1. The results indicated that most possible inorganic interferents, such as 500-fold concentration of KCl, Na2SO4, MgCl2, CaCl2, ZnCl2, FeCl3, Na2CO3, Cu(NO3)2 did not interfere the detection with the peak current changes less than ± 5%. Although phenolic compounds were similar in structure, most of them did not show oxidation process in the selected potential range, such as p-nitrophenol, o-nitrophenol, hydroquinone, catechol. 100-fold concentration of these phenolic compounds did not interfere the detection of BPA. Phenol showed an oxidation peak in the selected potential range, but the peak potential was different from that of BPA. 50-fold concentration of phenol did not interfere the detection. These results exhibited that the prepared electrode had an excellent anti-interference ability.

sections.heading: 3.10. Analysis applications
sections.text:
In order to evaluate applicability of the proposed method, the
CMK-3/nano-CILPE was used to detect BPA leaching from polycarbonate (PC) drinking bottle and plastic bag. The plastic pieces and ultrapure water were added into a beaker which was sealed with aluminium foil. The samples were boiled for 2 hours and then cooled to room-temperature. After that, the plastic pieces were filtered, and a certain volume of sample solution was added into 0.1 M PBS (pH 7.0). BPA was detected with the fabricated electrode using standard addition method. The results are listed in Table 2. The recovery rates of the spiked samples were investigated and ranged from 98.9% to 101.8%, indicating that the proposed method was suitable for practical application.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
A sensitive and reliable electrochemical method based on CMK-3/nano-CILPE
was proposed for the determination of BPA. Due to large surface area and good adsorption capacity of CMK-3, high conductivity and catalytic activity of ionic liquid, the modified electrode exhibited good catalytic activity to BPA with enhanced oxidation peak current and decreased oxidation overpotential. This new method possessed some obvious advantages, such as low detection limit, simple preparation process, rapid response and low cost. The proposed method was successfully applied in the determination of BPA in real samples with satisfactory results.

metadata.abstractText: A simple bisphenol A (BPA) sensor was successfully fabricated based on ordered mesoporous carbon CMK-3 modified nano-carbon ionic liquid paste electrode (CMK-3/nano-CILPE). The nanostructure of CMK-3 and the surface morphologies of modified electrodes were characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Electrochemical properties of the fabricated electrodes were investigated by cyclic voltammetry (CV) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). The fabricated sensor displayed excellent electroactivity towards bisphenol A using linear sweep voltammetry (LSV). * Corresponding Author, Tel: +86-951-6980139; Fax: +86-951-6980139. E-mail: yonghongli2012@163.com (Y. Li). * Corresponding Author, Tel: +86-376-6391172; Fax: +86-376-6391172. E-mail: wanghaibohn@163.com (H. Wang). 2 Experimental conditions influencing the analytical performance of the modified electrode were optimized. Under optimal conditions, the oxidation peak current was proportional to BPA concentration in the range from 0.2 μM to 150 μM with a detection limit of 0.05 μM (S/N = 3). This method was successfully used for determination of BPA leached from drinking bottle and plastic bag with good recoveries.
